Award.AwardTitle: Integrating Ethics Education: Capacity-Building Workshops for Science and Engineering Faculty

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Ethics Education in Science and Engineering project will build capacity for faculty to educate graduate students about research ethics in the context of the research environment. This approach is grounded in and flows from extensive empirical evidence that standards of conduct depend as much or more on the work environment than on participation in isolated courses or online tutorials.
The four project objectives include: 1. Consensus Conference to develop a framework to build a curriculum for Capacity-Building Workshops. 2. Curriculum Development for the Workshops. 3. Capacity-Building Workshops. 4. Outcome Assessments: Revise and finalize the Workshop curriculum based on feedback from faculty participants and their graduate student trainees.

This project will pilot the proposed workshops in 8 public and 7 private graduate institutions, including 3 Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs). To foster approaches responsive to the globalization of the research community, the proposed Expert Panel includes a member with extensive academic connections in China, and Chinese graduate students will be among those assisting with key aspects of curriculum development.

Broader impacts will derive from the activities, outputs and outcomes of this project and will enhance graduate ethics education for STEM graduate students while promoting the development of a diverse community of researchers better prepared to model the highest standards of scientific conduct. Results of the project will be promptly and widely disseminated through workshops conducted by participating faculty, established research ethics websites as well as the new National Center for Professional and Research Ethics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Integrating Ethics Education:
Capacity-Building Workshops for Science and Engineering Faculty

It is widely understood that a fundamental part of the training and socialization of researchers should include a focus on the responsible conduct of research. Historically, this has been approached largely through the teaching of classroom courses. This project was based on the premise that classroom teaching should be at most only one part of such training. The goal was to develop a mechanism to empower faculty and other research group leaders to integrate conversations about responsible conduct of research into the context of their research groups and environment. This emphasis on teaching and learning in context encompasses many opportunities (such as research group meetings, journal clubs, and one-on-one mentoring) for faculty to engage trainees in exploring the ethical dimensions of science and engineering. This approach is grounded in extensive empirical evidence that the learning of standards of conduct depend as much or more on the environment in which we work than simply on participating in isolated courses or online tutorials.

To accomplish this goal, the following four steps were carried out. (1) In YEAR 1, a consensus conference was convened with national leaders in research ethics education to identify key elements to be incorporated in a curriculum for capacity-building workshops for science and engineering faculty. (2) In YEARS 1 and 2, a workshop curriculum was developed, reviewed, and refined based on guidance developed in the consensus conference. (3) Beginning in YEAR 2, workshops were convened in multiple settings throughout the US, and to some extent internationally, to refine the curriculum and approaches. These were initially taught only by the project PI and co-PI, next by engaging some of the faculty experts from the initial consensus conference, and ultimately by providing workshop materials to interested individuals who were new to the project. (4) Finally, in YEARS 3 and 4, workshops continued to be taught, and outcomes were assessed by surveys and evaluations to obtain feedback from faculty teaching and observing workshops, faculty participants in workshops, and trainees in research groups of those faculty. The final workshop curriculum, including an instructor’s guide, have now been finalized for national dissemination.

Intellectual Merit: This project resulted in a new educational resource designed to create long-term improvement in ethics education for graduate students in science and engineering. By targeting faculty-mentors as a primary audience and by focusing on teaching ethics in the context of the research environment, largely untapped opportunities to foster student learning can be more fully realized.

Broader Impacts: The activities, outputs and outcomes of this project promoted teaching, training and learning and will enhance the infrastructure for research and education through consensus-building, delivery of a broadly applicable curriculum, and ultimately development of a diverse community of researchers better prepared to model the highest standards of scientific conduct. Results of the project are being widely disseminated through workshops conducted by participating faculty, and established research ethics websites EthicsCORE, the Online Ethics Center, and Resources for Research Ethics Education.
